photos.duplicate: Duplicate. This is a framed version of image 0258.

photos.description: This photo is not Alderbrook Farm.  I cannot determine what farm that would be.  Wrong house and design in upper left, and barn is in wrong place.  Topography wrong also.

Early photo of Lodge building and recently built garage and woodshed on left (not painted yet).  Note the vertical log bulkhead replaced in the mid 50's with a concrete bulkhead.  The overhead ramp extending from the lodge porch to the stairway (unbuilt) to the left of the garage had not been constructed yet.  Also note the boat launch rail and track system from the platform on the left, and a smaller ramp on the right hand end which I believe was for access during construction.  My guess is this is circa 1935-40.   171 Jacobsen on the postcard is a reference to Jacobsen photography studios in Bellingham

photos.people: Majority of people from Bellingham area.  I recognize Louis Adelstein (3rd from left) a cigar chomping character from Bellingham.
photos.description: Very likely a small derby with the participants.  These were newsworthy events at that time.  To correct the notes below this is the wooden platform of the boathouse floor of the lodge, not the dock.

photos.date: Unknown but I think it was built post depression.
photos.description: A classic winter southeaster hitting the old Doe Bay dock, built as a community dock for freight and the US Mail.  There is no protection at Doe Bay and the dock was often damaged, ultimately falling into disrepair and torn down.  In the 40's and 50's the mailboat OSAGE came daily from Bellingham...

Most likely this was the seaplane from Bellingham owned and operated by Les Bergsma - he had a seaplane base on Lake Whatcom and often brought passengers to the Lodge or to early cabins in later years.  If he had a little extra time he would let me sit in the pilots seat!  Very exciting for me - probably about 8 yrs old at the time.  (Ken)

Light snowfall showing cabins 8, 9, and 10 in the back row.  A couple of these now make up the Dave and Sandra Durand's home by the Farmhouse. They trucked them up that narrow driveway!  Cabin 10 now belongs to Gary Ostle. Photos are pre-bathrooms, which were added with a little extension in the early 50's...

One on the left could possibly be a fellow named Vanderford who came every year and stayed in Cabin 4. Earl Jewel was a Bellingham business man who loved to fish the "Point" Photo is in front of the "oil room/tackle shop" where you could purchase gas and oil and rent boats, fishing rods, nets, gaff hooks, etc. (Ken)
